Patch Set 17: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as cebb28c2a0247ccefe6e14f290029358f3d66672
Don't need to update this variable, just add new timer mHwmonPollTimer
I think this would cause confusion so I modified it. Is it not good to change an existing variable name?
Ack
Is the HwmonPath always the first path in the list?
Currently or temporarily, there seems to be only one chassis intrusion sensor in a Chassis. I assume there can be only one file with the specified name in hwmon.
In that case, please add one warning message for two chassis sensors in one Chassis case.
Done
Should I also change to else if(*pType == IntrusionSensorType::gpio)?
Yes, I think so.
Done
"can't find matched I2C, GPIO or Hwmon configuration " is better in this case.
Ack
Please address the build failure
Is this newly proposed entity-manager config? https://github.com/openbmc/entity-manager/tree/master/schemas needs to be updated to support this
Because the hwmon name is specfied in Aspeed's driver, so I will hardcode it in the source code and eliminate the "Input" option without updating the schema.
can you link to the said driver? Is it supported in https://github.com/openbmc/linux?
Hi, thanks for your review. The driver is still in Aspeed's linux https://github.com/AspeedTech-BMC/linux/blob/aspeed-master-v5.15/drivers/hwmon/aspeed-chassis.c
Is there any plan to upstream?
They confirmed the driver will be upstreamed in the future.
Instead of just copying and duplicating the functions, please refactor the code to use inheritance and function override.
Sure, I will try it in another patch. Do you think I should refactor it first or wait until all of these are merged?
Can we keep only second log message dropping first one. Same information is conveyed by both lines.
ACK but I will keep the first log to acknowledge the hwmon value.
This be if constexpr. constexpr version will save on binary size.
Sorry, I don't get it. Can you clarify?

My bad. I missed "can" in comment.
If check can be constexpr. constexpr gets executed at compile time that will save on binary size if debug is disabled. Example
https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/blob/master/src/ExitAirTempSensor.cpp#L415
Ack
newValue can either be "HardwareIntrusion" or "Normal" making comparison with "unknown" redundant. First part of if check will always be true.
At first, I did not want to change much of what the author had done, but he seems to be out of all of this so ACK.

Depending on first argument type only subset of later argument will be meaningful. There doesn't seem to be any meaning of having gpioInterted, slaveAddr, busId if howmon is going to be used used for intrusion. Similarly pollSensorStatusByPch and pollSensorStatusByGpio will be dead code.
ChassisIntrusionSensor is holding three classes PCHIntrusionSensor, GPIOIntrusionSensor and now hwmonIntrusionSensor. Is this observation correct ? if so shouldn't we keep three separate classes rather pushing three things in one class with "type" as field to differentiate ? Would like to others thought on this.

@Zhikui also suggested refactoring this so I think I will create a base class and 3 child classes to inherit it. I also think I should do the work in another patch because there's a lot to change. Is it OK?
IMO it's better to use same PR. That way history of review discussion remains intact. @Zhikui what is your thought ?
Ack

nit
Suggest you to move this to function initHwmonDevicePath, as it is used there.

ACK. Hi, one question. Some people are requesting to refactor this sensor because there are a lot of redundant functions and function arguments here when the sensor can only be one out of 3 types at a time (old comments of the patch). I've already worked on it but I wonder if I should do this within this patch review for consistency or create another?
What happens to the newValue != "unknown" check?

The initialized values of newValue and mValue are both "unknown", so if the newValue is still unknown, the condition will not be reached, providing that mValue won't be changed anywhere except for inside updateValue().
Same as line 164

I see many places wer this function can fail. 
Can we use bool return type and make sure if readHwmon fails it is handled properly?
pollSensorStatusByHwmon won't be called when readHwmon failed along the way.
What is the logic here?
the value of the hwmon file is 1 if there is an intrusion and 0 if the chassis cover is closed.

if mValue == newValue then do you need to write 0 to refout?
or not required?
We do need, cuz if the current value in hwmon is 1, it won't be updated until we reset it to 0 (according to the driver).

Question:
Do you see logs in journal if std::cout is used?
I do. I noticed that I have to use std::cerr instead in setSensorValue() for the logs to be seen.
This can be kept out of try block rt?
Magic number.
Do you mean I  should pre-define the number?
Yeah, it should be reset even when we can't read from it.
Done
Done

nit
Can we log the error details we caught too.
Sure

nit 
You can remove this
Ack

It is not recommended to do this. 
If you really need to pass this pointer to lambda use weak pointer. 
Else it causes scope issues.
Done

What if we get an ec which is not boost::asio::error::operation_aborted? 
Shouldn't that be handled or logged??

Should pollSensorStatusByHwmon be called in such case?

I have referred other sensors and used this behavior. Maybe only operation_aborted ec matters in this async function. As I read some other places on the internet, I think other ec won't cause the handler to be called.
Refer to ADC sensor to get a better understanding.

pollSensorStatusByHwmon should be called from readHwmon. This is so that if you have let's say 110 sensors and read takes around 0.01 sec per sensor. Then total time taken = 110*0.01 = 11sec 

let's assume intrusionSensorPollSec = 10sec. Which means every 10 sec 110 sensor reads will be invoked. 

Now the issues is that we are pushing more read than we can process. So read a sensor only after it's previous read is completed + intrusionSensorPollSec later.
Done
Please take a look.
why only taking one?
Because I assume we can only have 1 chassis intrusion-detecting hardware sensor at a time?! Is it correct?

What do you think if the "Class" property is "Aspeed2600_hwmon"?
Hwmon is general, in the future, maybe another Hwmon driver is implemented, it has different method to read/write the chassis status.
I think I would leave it like that. If it is the case in the future, the implementer may change this.
It seems that you need to update this comment
Done
Why do you need to change chassisIntrusionSensor from an object to share_ptr?

Because I need to use weak_ptr for the looping in pollSensorStatus...() to avoid the issue that @Arun Lal K M pointed out. Using directly the object to call methods in a loop may cause it to be not aware of whether the object is still alive.

Can we break this up into two reviews
1. clean up existing and get ready to add a new type
2. Add the new type

To avoid a lot of the if statement, how about make
ChassisIntrusionSensor the base class and capture the common code. for example the main polling function. Add ChassisIntrusionSensorPch, ChassisIntrusionSensorGpio and ChassisIntrusionSensorHwmon as the derived class with specialized read function.  Or create a Reader class to encapsulate the read function.
Not much happening on this recently. Chau Ly, are you willing to have someone help to get this in?
Sorry, I will get back to this right away and will need your review. Thank you for offering help.
Hi, please also have a look at this, and the patch with new method added: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/62775
As a cleanup patch, these can be moved to after line 93
Done
As a cleanup patch, these can be moved to after line 98
Done
As a cleanup patch, these can be moved after line 102
Done
Do we want keep this behavior: open and close fd for every read cycle?
I chose to keep the fd open the whole sensor lifetime and close it when the sensor object is destroyed (in the destructor). Do you suggest any pros and cons?
This part can be common for different types
I moved the value conversion into the updateValue() and called updateValue() from pollSensorStatus() when the readSensor() function returns positive values. Can you please check?
we want to be consistent in all types, either throw on error and use try/catch in createSensor or just return an inactive sensor
I throw error when there's failure in initializing attributes for both sensor types, and try/catch in createSensorsFromConfig. Is there any missing detail that I didn't notice?

For the gpio you have try/catch inside constructor, your constructor would never throw. What I am suggesting is to be consistent, for non-recoverable errors, throw inside constructor or all outside the constructor for all sensor types.
Oh I see, I removed the try/catch in the gpio constructor and let the std::exception error catch where the object construction is called catch them also.
I think it is better if this method is not virtual. I expect that all of the sensor have the same behavior for this.
Are you think about having timer polling for all the method?
Yes

I think there could be
1. one private read() function that is virtual, where it just reads the GPIO or PCH into a binary value
2. one common setStatus(value), where convert the 0/1 to "HardwareIntrusion" or "normal"
Why the default value is "pch"?

This is the expectation from the old design, pch is the first element in the enum which is zero and can be automatically assigned to mType without explicitly doing so, but I have to do this because of the CI failure asking for initial value setting.
This is not needed.
Since I changed to re-initializing every re-scan, removed this.

I think you should not dynamic cast from ChassisIntrusionSensor to ChassisIntrusionGpioSensor. You can define a new method compareSensor in the ChassisIntrusionSensor class. If you do that, you don't have to define getGpioInverted, getBusId and getSlaveAddr methods
If compareSensor function is used, it has to take different type and number of params for each derived class which is I think not neccessary.
you can pass baseConfiguration to this method.
Then it has to extract configs which I think is not suitable to be executed in the sensor class.
I don't think it is ok to pass configuration to a function. If you don't want to do that, you can pass a variant argument.

Somehow I think this is a little cumbersome, and I also wonder if we do need to handle rescaning intrusion sensor config. Because this is a sensor on BMC, we won't have a chance to rescan if the BMC is replaced...?!
Looks like only a single intrusion sensor is supported. Why not always re-initialize?
I removed the comparison stuffs and let it re-initialize every rescan if there's a sensor config.
Thanks for separating the original patch.

In the old design, when reading I2C done, it releases this i2c channel via calling close function, other applications can use this i2c channel. But I see that in the new design, you are not releasing i2c channel. Is it correct?

I was enlighted before by Andrew that opening an fd on the bus does not cause it to be busy to other clients. It only really touches the bus the moment it issues an i2c command and blocks other fds. Please check the line and correct my explanation if it's wrong
https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/tree/drivers/i2c/i2c-dev.c?h=v5.19-rc7#n595
nit: remove this blank line to pass verification
Oh thanks, I ran local CI for all the commits and it seemed to be not aware of the errors of the first commit alone.
nit: remove this blank line to pass verification
Done
This plus the other patch worked for me.
These can be called in init (constructor), no need to recheck for every read, right?
Yes, thank you.
this can be after line157
Done
Done
nit: no need to add void
Done
Add clarification, only one type of intrusion is expected for a given system
Done. Thank you.
Looking good now. Only some small things

nit: = defaultPollSec;
and move after line 47
Done
These two strings are used in multiple places, use constexpr, so it only need to be defined in one place.
Done
busId can be 0
Done
Reading through again, notice few more things that were missed.
why is this changed from != NormalStr? This changes the power on behavior since mOldValue is initialized to unknown
Because when the chassis cover is properly close, logging the de-assert event every time BMC boots up is not correct right?
maybe, but it can be a different patch to change that behavior. With the code now, will there be an assert if the intrusion is true on power on?
yes it’ll log both before or after my patch.
Done
not needed
Done
